abstract.p: This article proposes a component-level predictive maintenance scheduling framework in which system residual life prediction information is utilized. In the proposed framework, predictive maintenance scheduling is only triggered when a system is close to failure. A lifetime margin is used to infer that a system is close to failure but still safely operational when predictive maintenance scheduling is triggered. Some technical elements are detailed to facilitate the implementation of the proposed framework. A simulation study based on an example predictive maintenance scheduling framework (framework B) is provided to illustrate the implementation of the proposed framework, and compare framework B with the corresponding counterpart only consisting of predictive maintenance scheduling models (framework A). Given a relatively low noise level of system degradation processes, compared with the classical prognostics framework only consisting of predictive maintenance scheduling models, the proposed framework is similarly effective in failure prevention and more economic in that several premature preventive maintenance acts are saved.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The complexity and importance of an effective maintenance strategy is widely recognized in today’s competitive market. In the recent decades, more and more research efforts are targeted toward condition-based maintenance (CBM) and predictive maintenance (PdM).1,2 The main motivations of developing a CBM/PdM strategy are catastrophic failure reduction, cost minimization, system safety, availability maximization, and platform reliability improvement.3 As many systems undergo degradation processes which are reflected by the change of their states (e.g. crack length) or performance (e.g. vibration amplitude) before failures,4 adopting CBM/PdM programs usually reveals the systems’ actual states with more certainty.5 In the literature, there are many research works that report the effectiveness of CBM/PdM programs.1,2

A CBM/PdM program has three main phases: (a) data acquisition; (b) signal processing; and (c) maintenance decision support.1 Techniques for maintenance decision support can be further divided into two categories: diagnostics and prognostics. Diagnostics deals with fault detection, isolation, and identification when it occurs, while prognostics deals with fault prediction before it occurs.1

There are mainly two aspects of prognostics: residual life (RL) prediction and CBM/PdM scheduling.1 RL prediction tends to predict the time duration between the current moment and the moment when the system fails to perform its desired function. CBM/PdM scheduling tends to schedule preventive maintenance (PM) acts that optimize the objective function (e.g. maintenance cost per unit of operation time, overall maintenance cost, average system availability, etc.) based on the system’s monitored performance. Techniques for RL prediction include physics-based (first principle-based) approaches6–9 and data-driven approaches.10–13 It is pointed out that a decent RL prediction approach should not only provide the prediction itself, but the confidence associated with that prediction as well.14 On the other hand, most scheduling models are built on stochastic degradation processes (e.g. gamma process15) or Makov models;16 few research works address on-line PdM scheduling that captures the changing state of an individual system in a real-time manner.17–20

Currently, there are many works on CBM/PdM scheduling,1,21,40 and more works on RL prediction.1,2,22,23 However, a PdM scheduling framework that utilizes the information of a system’s predicted RL (PRL) for reducing premature PM acts has not been identified yet. It is important to recognize that both aspects of prognostics are important and cannot take the place of each other. RL prediction provides an estimation of the time to failure which provides early alarm of a close-to-failure situation, but lacks the capability of determining when to perform PM acts. PdM scheduling determines the optimal PM schedules, but may sometimes be unnecessarily conservative and recommend premature PM acts.

In this article, we propose a PdM scheduling framework that takes advantage of system RL prediction information. In the proposed framework, PdM scheduling is triggered only when the RL prediction results reveal that the system is close to failure (i.e. most of the system’s lifetime has been used up). The principle technical details will be detailed to facilitate the use of the proposed framework. An example framework and a numerical example are also provided to illustrate the implementation of the proposed framework.

The rest of the article is organized as follows: ‘Modeling’ section proposes the PdM scheduling framework utilizing RL prediction information. ‘Evaluation’ section conducts an extensive numerical simulation to illustrate the implementation procedures of the proposed framework, and compare the proposed framework with the associated PdM scheduling model that does not use RL prediction information. The final section concludes the article and discusses some future directions.

sec.title: Modeling
sec.p: In this section, the PdM framework utilizing RL prediction information is formulated in ‘The PdM scheduling framework’ section. Several key technical elements are discussed in ‘Technical elements’ section. Finally, ‘an example PdM framework’ is provided.

sec.title: The PdM scheduling framework
sec.p:
First of all, the general assumptions under the proposed framework are summarized as follows to clarify the applicability of the proposed framework:
Assumption 1: the research object is a single-component system, that is, we consider component-level prognostics in this article.
Assumption 2: the system is continuously monitored.
Assumption 3: PM acts can be performed immediately upon requirement, that is, all maintenance resources (including personnel, tools, etc.) have been prepared when a PM act needs to be performed. This assumption can be relaxed as will be discussed later.
Assumption 4: the duration and cost of a PM act are independent of the system s state when the PM act is performed.

With the above assumptions, the PdM scheduling framework is outlined in Figure 1. Figure 1.
The PdM scheduling framework utilizing RL prediction information, where y represents ‘yes’ and n represents ‘no’.
PdM: predictive maintenance; RL: residual life.

In Figure 1, module A represents the functionality of RL prediction and module B represents the functionality of on-line PdM scheduling. PRL (t )≤Ω is the trigger condition that switches the use of module A to module B, where PRL(t) is the PRL at time t and Ω a lifetime margin which will be detailed later. Δt is the updating step length. T* (t ) is the most upcoming PM schedule calculated at time t and Tend is the time when system operation is terminated and thus RL prediction and PdM scheduling are no longer necessary. In both module A and module B, the updating mechanism is a feature of on-line RL prediction and PdM scheduling, which captures the system’s changing state in a real-time manner.18–20

Basically, the idea behind the proposed framework is: one begins to schedule PM acts only when most of the system’s lifetime is used up; however, the system should not fail before maintenance scheduling.

To trigger PdM scheduling only when the system is close to failure is motivated by one’s desire of fully utilizing a system’s useful life before maintenance. In a PdM scheduling model which does not utilize RL prediction information, it is possible to perform PM acts when a system is still decently far from failure. This problem may exist in PdM scheduling models considering imperfect PM where modified system lifetime distributions are used to model the effect of imperfect PM,18,20 or in PdM scheduling models with finite planning horizon where modified/unmodified system lifetime distributions are used to model the system’s failure likelihood after a PM act.24 Qualitatively, this is because that the determination of the optimal PM schedules is not only based on the system-specific RL distribution which does reveal the specific system’s current status, but also based on the population-oriented lifetime distribution which only provides general prognostic information. This will be illustrated in a more quantitative way in ‘An example framework’ and ‘Evaluation’ sections.

On the other hand, one needs to guarantee that the system does not fail before starting PdM scheduling. If the system fails before maintenance scheduling, then the proposed framework is ineffective and is no better than a classical corrective maintenance (CM) program which simply allows a system to run to failure.

Based on the above two considerations, it shows that the lifetime margin Ω in the trigger condition should be relatively small which represents the expectation that the system is close to failure, but on the other hand, it should guarantee that the system does not fail when PRL>Ω. To obtain deeper insights into Ω, we have the proposition below.Proposition 1
For one system (system A), if the lifetime margin Ω corresponds to its ARL=Ψ·Δt where Ψ is a positive counting number and Ψ≥1, then system A will not fail before starting PdM scheduling.Proof
First, we denote the time when system A reaches its ARL=Ψ·Δt as TA. Suppose that system A is operating at time t and a RL prediction model provides PRL with updating step length Δt. Through the RL prediction techniques, we have PRL(t). If system A’s PRL is proportional to its actual RL (ARL) before its PRL reaches Ω, i.e. PRL (t1 )<PRL (t2 )⇔ARL (t1 )<ARL (t2 ), where ARL (t2 )>ARL (t1 )≥Ψ·Δt, then PdM scheduling will be triggered at time TA before system failure. If system A’s PRL is not absolutely proportional to its ARL before its PRL reaches Ω, i.e. there are cases PRL (t3 )<Ω with ARL (t3 )>Ψ·Δt, then PdM scheduling will also be triggered at time t3 before system failure.□

Proposition 1 provides the condition which guarantees that the system does not fail before PdM scheduling. On the other hand, to make sure that most of the system’s lifetime is used up, we choose Ω*= [Ω corresponding to min (ARL=Ψ·Δt ) ], where Ω* denotes the optimal value of Ω. Based on Proposition 1, we have Ω*= [Ω corresponding to ARL=Δt ]. Herein, we have determined the optimal value of Ω in Figure 1, for one system.

In practice, however, it is infeasible to obtain Ω* for a system as its ARL is scarcely (almost never) available before failure. To conquer this difficulty, we propose deriving the mapping between PRL and ARL empirically from historical record, as discussed in the following. Given the historical record containing N systems’ degradation processes from initialization to failure without PM acts, their ARL at any operation time t is known and the associated PRL can be obtained based on a RL prediction model. To obtain the optimal value of Ω, we need to have PRLj (t ) when ARLj (t )=Δt,j=1,2,…,N, where PRLj (t ) and ARLj (t ) are PRL and ARL of system j at time t, respectively. Afterward, the optimal value of Ω is defined as (1)Ω*≡maxj=1,2,…,N {PRLj (t )corresponding to ARLj (t )=Δt }
Note that the empirical definition of Ω* in equation (1) is to guarantee that each (at least most of) system does not fail before PdM scheduling (entering module B).

sec.title: Technical elements
sec.p: The proposed PdM scheduling framework is established once the optimal value of lifetime margin Ω is determined. In this section, several technical elements are discussed in more depth to facilitate the implementation of the proposed framework.

The first issue to be discussed is the connection between RL prediction and on-line PdM scheduling. The PRL of system j at time t can be given as1 (2)E [Λ |Λ>0,Zj (t ) ] where Λ denotes the random variable of the system’s RL, t the current time/age, and Zj (υ ) the past system condition profile up to time υ. In practice, there exists uncertainty in RL prediction due to (a) the measuring/monitoring errors, (b) the inherent variability of Zj (t ), and (c) the error in choosing a prediction model. And the cdf of the RL distribution is (3)⪻ [Λ>0 |Zj (t ) ] where the probability distribution defined in equation (3) is typically called RL distribution.25,26 As the probability distribution in equation (3) is estimated based on the system’s measurable real-time degradation indicators Zj (υ ), it is sometimes called performance reliability or real-time reliability.27–29 By equations (2) and (3), we have (4)PRLj (t )=∫0 ∞ [γ·⪻ (Λ=γ |Λ>0,Zj (t ),γ>0 ) ]dγ where ⪻ (Λ=γ |Λ>0,Zj (t ),γ>0 ) is the predicted pdf of the system’s RL. Note that in some cases, PRL is estimated as the median of the RL distribution stead of the mean.25

While RL prediction tends to obtain the mean of RL distribution in equation (2), on-line PdM scheduling tends to identify the optimal PM schedules based on (or partially based on) the predicted RL distribution in equation (3). This is similar as the relationship between mean RL estimation and PM scheduling in classical lifetime distribution-based reliability analysis.30,31 To be more concrete, the essential elements of a maintenance scheduling model are summarized as follows:
Objective of the maintenance program (e.g. minimization of maintenance cost rate,32 minimization of overall maintenance cost,24 maximization of average system availability,15 etc.).
Maintenance policy reflects the general framework of performing PM acts, which could be periodic,31 control-limit,32 sequential,20,33 etc.
Maintenance quality (effect of maintenance), which could be perfect that improves the system to a state ‘as good as new’, imperfect, minimal, etc.30
Degradation/failure characteristics, which quantifies a system’s failure likelihood. The degradation/failure characteristics are mostly system lifetime distribution,30,31 RL distribution (performance reliability), or a mixture.18–20,24
Constraints, which could be limitation of maintenance resources,24 maintenance conflicts among components of a multi-component system,24 etc.

From the above analysis, it shows that, compared with RL prediction, PdM scheduling is more complex and requires a more comprehensive knowledge besides the system’s degradation characteristics (i.e. condition monitoring information). In the next section, an example PdM scheduling framework will be provided with more mathematical details.

The second issue to be discussed is the condition for stopping model update and performing a PM act: T* (t )-t≤Δt (shown in Figure 1), which is in associate with the third general assumption in ‘The PdM scheduling framework’ section. Suppose that system j’s upcoming PM schedule estimated at time t is Tj * (t ), there are two possible results: (1) Tj * (t )-t≤Δt, which means that the upcoming optimal PM schedule is near in the future and we cannot wait for model update at time t+Δt (≥Tj * (t ) ), consequently a PM act should be performed immediately; (2) Tj * (t )-t>Δt, which means that, based on the system condition monitoring information up to the current moment, there is still some time left (i.e. Tj * (t )-t) before the desired time for the next PM act. Now we have two choices: to perform the PM act right at time t, or to wait until the next model update. According to the third general assumption in ‘The PdM scheduling framework’ section, a PM act can be performed immediately upon requirement. Therefore, based on the current estimate, we can still let the system operate for Tj * (t )-t-Δt (>0 ) then perform the PM act. On the other hand, more recent information about the system’s state close to failure can be obtained by allowing the system to continue to operate (remember that PdM scheduling is triggered only when a system is expected to be close to failure). Therefore, a final choice when Tj * (t )-t>Δt is to allow the system continue to operate and update the PdM scheduling model at time t+Δt (if system j does not fail before/at time t+Δt).

Finally, we note that the third general assumption in ‘The PdM scheduling framework’ section can be relaxed in practice, as all necessary resources can be prepared in advance when the PRL indicates an alarm of close-to-failure situation.

sec.title: An example framework
sec.p: This section provides an example prognostics framework. The purpose is three-fold: first, to provide a concrete PdM scheduling framework; second, to enhance the analysis in ‘Technical elements’ section with more mathematical details; third, to introduce the PdM scheduling framework that will be further utilized in the next section.

To establish a PdM scheduling framework utilizing system RL prediction, an approach for RL/RL distribution prediction and a PdM scheduling model are needed. In the example PdM scheduling framework herein, the RL/RL distribution prediction approach is from Gebraeel et al.,25 while the PdM scheduling model is a simplified version of that in Camci.24 It should be noted that the choice of the specific RL/RL distribution prediction approach and PdM scheduling model is for illustration purpose, while the proposed framework is generic and does not rely on any specific model. Thus, many models for RL/RL prediction and PdM scheduling in the literature1,2 can be integrated into the proposed framework according to practical needs.

In the following, we first review the RL and RL distribution prediction approach in Gebraeel et al.25 named as sensory updated degradation model (SUDM). The SUDM is generally appropriate for systems where preliminary and partial degradation accelerates the degradation process.19 The essential structure of the SUDM can be summarized as follows.

Using the elements in Table 1, we adapt a simplified PdM scheduling model from Camci24 for single-component systems. The adapted and reorganized PdM scheduling model is summarized as follows, which highlights the updating characteristics of the model.

The objective of the PdM scheduling model is to minimize the cumulative system risk (CSR) associated with system failures and PM acts, which is counted in terms of costs. An underlying assumption for the PdM scheduling model is that the system is non-repairable and is entirely replaced by a new one upon failure (i.e. CM is perfect). However, the system health can be improved by a PM act to a state ‘as good as new’ (i.e. PM is perfect). The expected CSR at the end of operation (at time Tend) can be calculated as (11)CSR (Tend )=FC (Tend )+PMC (Tend ) where CSR (Tend ) is the expected CSR up to time Tend, FC (Tend ) the expected system’s cumulative failure cost (SCFC) up to time Tend that includes CM cost and cost of operation downtime, and PMC (Tend ) the expected system’s cumulative PM cost (SCPMC) up to time Tend. Qualitatively, the occurrence of a system failure increases operation downtime and CM cost (i.e. increases SCFC), but cancels the planned PM acts (i.e. reduces SCPMC). Contrarily, performing a PM act increases SCPMC, but reduces the risk of system failure (i.e. reduces SCFC). Therefore, a careful balance between unexpected system failure and redundant PM acts is needed to fully benefit from a maintenance program. In the PdM scheduling model using real-time condition monitoring information, equation (11) is more specifically adapted as (12)CSR (Tend |Z (t ) )=C (t )+ [FC (Tend |Z (t ) ) + PMC (Tend |Z (t ) ) ] where Z (t ) is the system condition profile up to the current time t, C (t ) the actual cumulative cost including SCFC and SCPMC up to time t and is a constant which does not influence the calculation of the optimal PM schedules at time t. CSR (Tend |Z (t ) ) represents the expected CSR in time interval [t,Tend ] conditional on the system’s condition profile up to time t, and similar interpretations hold for FC (Tend |Z (t ) ) and PMC (Tend |Z (t ) ). The formulation in equation (12) highlights the updating (dynamic) feature of the PdM scheduling model.

In equation (12), FC (Tend |Z (t ) ) is counted as (13)FC (Tend |Z (t ) )=FL·CP (Tend |Z (t ) ) where FL is the loss per system failure and CP (υ |Z (t ) ) the predicted cumulative system failure probability up to time υ≥t conditional on the system condition profile up to time t, which is to be detailed later. On the other hand, PMC (Tend |Z (t ) ) is counted as (14)PMC (Tend |Z (t ) )=PML·∑υ=t Tend [ (1-CP (υ |Z (t ) ) ) · X (υ |Z (t ) ) ] where PML is the cost per PM act, X (υ |Z (t ) ) the indicator function where υ≥t, and X (υ |Z (t ) )=1 if a PM act is scheduled at time υ based on the system’s condition profile up to time t and X (υ |Z (t ) )=0 otherwise. In equation (14), the term (1-CP (υ |Z (t ) ) ) is used to account for the effect of unexpected system failure in canceling the planned PM acts. Substituting equations (13) and (14) into equation (12), we have (15)CSR (Tend |Z (t ) )=C (t )+FL·CP (Tend |Z (t ) ) +PML·∑υ=t Tend [ (1-CP (υ |Z (t ) ) ) · X (υ |Z (t ) ) ]

Equation (15) is the objective function to be minimized to determine the optimal PM schedules based on the system condition profile up to time t. Note that in equation (15), it is not specified that the PM acts are periodic or should be performed once a reliability characteristic (e.g. hazard rate) reaches a threshold value, the only condition is that the PM acts are performed sequentially (i.e. sequential maintenance policy).

Finally, the calculation of CP (υ |Z (t ) ) is detailed, which is closely related with the effect of PM acts and the degradation characteristics. To calculate CP (υ |Z (t ) ), it is necessary to take into account the effect of PM acts in improving system health and reducing its failure risk, and we have24 (16)CP (tk |Z (t ) )=CP (Tk |Z (t ) )+ [1-CP (Tk |Z (t ) ) ] ·P (tk-Tk |Z (t ) ) where tk denotes the time after the kth scheduled PM act (after time t) and before the (k + 1)th scheduled PM act (after time t), Tk the moment of the kth scheduled PM act and Tk<tk, and P (tk-Tk |Z (t ) ) the cumulative system failure probability counted during time interval (Tk,tk ), naturally we have CP (t0 |Z (t ) )=P (t0-t |Z (t ) ), where t0≥t. To be more concrete, suppose that m PM acts are scheduled in the time interval (t,Tend ), then we have (17)CP (Tend |Z (t ) )=CP (Tm |Z (t ) ) + [1-CP (Tm |Z (t ) ) ]·P (Tend-Tm |Z (t ) )CP (Tm |Z (t ) )=CP (Tm-1 |Z (t ) ) + [1-CP (Tm |Z (t ) ) ]·P (Tm-Tm-1 |Z (t ) ):CP (T1 |Z (t ) )=P (T1-t |Z (t ) )

By equation (17), CP (Tend |Z (t ) ) can be calculated recursively provided that the functional form of P (· |Z (t ) ) can be determined, and the schedules of PM acts are given (which are to be optimized). To compute P (· |Z (t ) ), it is proposed that the system’s RL distribution (equation (10)) is used to estimate P (T1-t |Z (t ) ) and the modified/unmodified system’s lifetime distribution is used to estimate the rest (i.e. P (T1-T2 |Z (t ) ),…,P (Tm-Tm-1 |Z (t ) ), P (Tend-Tm |Z (t ) ) This is because that a PM act may significantly interrupt the system’s condition profile, making it hard to obtain a reliable prediction of the evolution of the system’s condition hereafter.5 Thus, the system’s lifetime distribution provides an appropriate way to estimate its failure likelihood after a PM act. Similar approach is also suggested in previous works.18,20,24 To account for the effect of PM acts, the system’s lifetime distribution could be modified or unmodified. Herein, we have covered the mathematical formulation of module A and module B in Figure 1. For convenience, a classical PdM scheduling framework only using PdM scheduling model (equation (15)) is denoted as framework A, and the example PdM scheduling framework utilizing system RL prediction information is denoted as framework B (i.e. the proposed framework). In the next section, a numerical example will be presented to illustrate the implementation of the proposed framework, and compare framework B with framework A.

sec.title: Evaluation
sec.p: This section conducts a simulation study to illustrate the use of the proposed framework. We first describe the preparation of the necessary data in ‘Data generation’ section. In ‘Implementation and results’ section, we discuss the implementation process and the results. Finally, a comparison between framework A and framework B is performed to gain more insights into the proposed framework.

sec.title: Data generation
sec.p:
This section prepares the data necessary for implementing framework A and framework B. There are three groups of data to be generated, as summarized in Table 2. Table 2.

Note that when multiple degradation indicators are responsible for system failure, the critical level D becomes a critical surface.35 In practice, there are also cases when system failures are observable but hard to define by a deterministic critical level/surface in the space of measurable degradation indicators (i.e. the system state is not directly observable28 or people’s knowledge about the critical level/surface is fuzzy36). There are approaches for such cases, for example, proportional hazards model,37 hidden Markov model,38 logistic regression model,39 residual delay-time model,26 etc.

The degradation process can be simulated by defining the values of μ0, σ0, μ1', σ1, and σ in equation (7), while the objective function (equation (15)) at a certain time t can be established by further defining some parameter values (the third type of data in Table 2 and D). sec.title: Implementation and results
sec.p: Based on the data generated in ‘Data generation’ section, this section implements the example PdM scheduling framework on the 100 testing samples in a real-time manner from time t = 1 to time t = Tend. In the implementation process of one testing sample, the same degradation process (e.g. one degradation process in Figure 2) is used to evaluate the effect of Tend on the performance differences between framework A and framework B. Note that this also corresponds to the effect of perfect PM acts. The PM duration is not considered in the planning horizon as it does not influence system operation.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This section discusses the comparison results in Table 6 and Figure 4 in more details.

First of all, by Table 6, it is observed that same numbers of system failures occur in two frameworks. It is easy to understand that a system will fail in framework B if it fails in framework A, as no PM acts will be performed according to the PdM scheduling model no matter when the functionality of PdM scheduling is triggered. However, on the other hand, a system might fail in framework B if it does not fail in framework A. It is possible that a system fails even before the functionality of PdM scheduling is triggered in framework B. Therefore, the number of system failures in framework B is theoretically no smaller than the number of system failures in framework A. However, in the entire simulation process, no samples fail before the functionality of PdM scheduling is triggered using the lifetime margin Ω*. It is noticed that, for the case of σ=0.1, there are two testing samples with PRL = 7.66 > Ω* and PRL = 7.32 > Ω*, respectively, when their ARL = 1. However, they have PRL < Ω* at earlier stage of their lifetimes and thus the functionality of PdM scheduling is still triggered before failures. Also, we have observed three similar testing samples for the case of σ=0.3 and one similar testing sample for the case of σ=0.5. Finally, it is reasonable to expect very similar numbers of system failures in two frameworks, provided that a generally large number of training samples are available for determining Ω*.

By Figure 4, it is observed that, for a given noise level σ, the difference in the numbers of performed PM acts in two frameworks is insensitive with respect to Tend. That is, the increase of system operation duration does not significantly increase the performance differences between two frameworks. To investigate this observation, statistical analysis is conducted for the testing samples with long operation duration (i.e. Tend=200h). By Figure 1, the PRL at the time when PM acts are performed in framework A essentially determines the performance difference between two frameworks. In framework A, we calculate the PRL at the schedules of the performed PM acts for each testing sample whose last four maintenance acts before t=Tend are all PM acts. Afterward, the mean and variance of the PRL at the schedules of the last kth PM acts can be calculated, as summarized in Table 7, where k = 1, 2, 3, 4. Table 7.

In Table 7, the results for each σ show that early PM acts (when PRL is still large) are generally likely to be scheduled as the last one or two PM acts in framework A when it is close to Tend. However, the effect of finite Tend (together with the system’s lifetime distribution) on scheduling premature PM work acts are mostly limited to the last two PM acts. Such effect quickly degrades when it comes to the last third and fourth PM acts. Consequently, the condition PRL (t )≤Ω in framework B usually only puts off the schedules of the last one or two PM acts in framework A, which leads to the decrease of the number of performed PM acts. Therefore, the performance difference between two frameworks depends mostly on the schedules of the last one or two PM acts in framework A. That is, regardless of the value of Tend, usually only the schedules of the last one or two PM acts in framework A determine the performance difference between the two frameworks.

By Figure 4, it is also observed that, for a given Tend, the difference between the numbers of the performed PM acts is inversely proportional to the noise level σ. With increased σ, the degradation indicator becomes more fluctuating and leads to increased Ω*. Comparing Ω* in Table 4 with the results of PRL at the schedules of last kth PM acts in framework A presented in Table 7, it shows that, for Tend=200h, more PM schedules tend to be adjusted in framework B for σ=0.1 than for σ=0.3 and σ=0.5, which will further lead to larger difference between the numbers of performed PM acts in two frameworks. For σ=0.5, it is noticed that PdM scheduling is triggered for most samples at very early stage of the testing systems’ lifetimes with large value of Ω*, and framework B performs equally as framework A. Note that, theoretically, framework B reduces to framework A when Ω→∞.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article proposes a component-level PdM scheduling framework that utilizes system RL prediction information for reducing the number of premature PM acts. In the proposed framework, PdM scheduling is triggered only when most of a system’s lifetime is used up. A lifetime margin is used to infer that the system is close to failure but still safely operational. A numerical example based on an example framework is provided to illustrate the implementation of the proposed framework. Compared with a PdM scheduling framework which does not utilize RL prediction information, the implementation results provide evidence that the proposed framework is similarly effective in failure prevention and more economic in that fewer premature PM acts are performed, provided that the noise level of the degradation process is relatively low.

In the future, more systematic comparisons between the proposed framework and other prognostics framework are necessary to fully understand the applicability of the proposed framework. It is also valuable to extend the current framework to a system-level framework for multi-component systems.
